messageBody:
On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Chermside, Michael wrote:
> Some are less obvious, but I'm still clear on what to do. For instance,
> writing tests that include the database are often QUITE difficult. Not
> everyone has a copy of Oracle; we can't just erase tables willy-nilly
> to set up for each test; etc. So I will use mock objects (hopefully
> starting from those at www.mockobjects.com) to simulate the connection,
> and other "external" data sources/sinks.

You may want to consider staying away from putting any logic in the
database (i.e. PL/SQL). We have a lot of business logic in our database
and it makes testing difficult because mocking the database would require
re-implementing the logic in Java.


> QUESTION 1:
> Where do my JUnit unit tests go?
>
> I see 3 likely answers... (a) make each an inner class of the
> class being tested, (b) for every class "Foo" have a class called
> "TestFoo" in the same package, or (c) have a separate (but parallel
> hierarchy of classes... SOURCE/com/pkg/Foo.java is tested by
> TEST/com/pkg/TestFoo.java.
>
> I lean towards (c) because it makes it easy to build the "real" code
> and the "test" code separately, and omit the "test" code from
> production deployment. Are there other significant issues here?

I use (b) and (c) on different projects. I like (b) better because it's a
lot easier to find a test (it's right there in the same directory as the
code). We prefix our tests with "_" and suffix them with "Test" to make
them easier to find (so a test for the String class would be
"_StringTest").

We deploy the test cases along with the production code because it's easy
and we have no reason not to. But it wouldn't be too hard to jar up
everything that doesn't start with "_".


> QUESTION 2:
> How do I automatically build the suite of all tests?

We coded up a TestSuite that finds all the tests in the project (which is
pretty fast because they all start with "_" so we don't have to use
"instanceof" to figure out if they are tests or not) and executes them.

We also threw in some fun options like only running tests in certain
packages and running the tests in order of their execution speed (we have
some really slow tests, which I know is bad, but there's not too much we
can do about it).

It can also run just those tests that have been compiled in the last 10
minutes plus tests for any classes that have been compiled in the last 10
minutes. (So if you modify method A.foo() and class B calls A.foo(), then
_ATest and _BTest will be executed.) This is to get around the problem of
our test suite being really slow, which is something that I want to fix
but cannot (for non-technical reasons).


Also, our development environment, IntelliJ IDEA, allows us to select a
directory or package and run all the tests it finds.

IDEA also has the very handy ability to run all the test methods in the
test case that you are currently editing, or just the test method that the
text cursor is currently in. (And it will run them in the debugger too if
you like. So debugging a test case is as simple as putting a breakpoint in
the test method, putting the text cursor in that method, and then hitting
the keyboard shortcut for debug.)


Erik
